content: There doesn't seem to exist an equivalent of docs#CategoryTheory.OverClass for Under categories. Should we add it?

Why not? And if you want a more challenging project you could write a @[to_opposite] attribute like @[to_additive] which means that you can just tag all the lemmas about overclasses with it and it will automatically generate the corresponding UnderClass lemmas.
I haven't tested it with anything in category theory yet, but (some slight variation of?) the order_dual attribute I've been hacking on here might be able to do that sort of thing.
I don't think we should. Unless you have a very good reason. See the warning in the docstring of the file.
Good point, I don't know that I have a good enough reason at the moment. Though it is slightly frustrating that we don't have a typeclass like this for the category of commutative algebras.
Those are not commutative by default, which is annoying when I want to work with schemes over a base.
I don't think I understand. I think the action is commutative by default?
What I meant is that the algebra itself need not be commutative.
This is not a big issue though, I can just work with the Under category.
I agree that we shouldn't have CommAlgebraCat and use Under instead (which I assume is what you meant). But I am saying above that you probably could use docs#Algebra instead of some "UnderClass".
Michał Mrugała has marked this topic as resolved.
